text: <@U06DFL7BP> I have never been more glad that my truck has no fancy computers in it. the only electronic thing in it is the tape deck.

i did some in-dash projects at a previous company and the lead times on tech are so long that you end up with 6 year old hardware in your dash, and the software dev is focused on making something in 2015 run like it should on 2009 hardware rather than not blowing up your car
<https://youtu.be/ZerV5WcnBAo>

text: Is there a good (free) proxy tool out there? I really like <http://www.charlesproxy.com/> but I misplaced my license

attachments.text: Charles Web Debugging Proxy - Official Site
attachments.fallback: Charles Web Debugging Proxy - Official Site

text: Or would Uncorked buy me a license for Charles?
my proxy is the best
biased
oh i've used charles before
what are you doing with it?
(that would help with the "free alternative" question)
I'm using `node` terminal to make calls to Harvest API, and I want to inspect headers on request and response
hm.
can't node just tell you that
I could try finding a way to use chrome extension to make the same request, but I specifically want to know what the `harvest` node package is doing to the request
I don't know how to get node to tell me that
Would Postman help with any of that?
you using the harvest official api or node-harvest?
I'm using node-harvest. I'm not sure how to use "harvest official api". as I understand it, they don't have an official node package
oh oh oh i see
thought you were making the calls by hand
I'm making the calls in Terminal, in a `node` shell.
someday I hope to make the same calls from server/app code
using the same package (node-harvest) <https://www.npmjs.com/package/harvest>
more about my problem: if I authenticate with user/password it works fine. If I try to authenticate with oauth token/secret it doesn't. I asked Harvest support for help. They want to see my headers.
looks like node-harvest uses restler under the covers
Does a combo of using something like Postman to look at requests/responses and looking at node-harvest source do the job?
thats where i was going
you can actually probably cut postman out
<https://github.com/log0ymxm/node-harvest/blob/master/index.js>

attachments.text: node-harvest - Node.js Client API for the Harvest time tracking service

text: ~line 32
<@U027PV4AP|stephanie> has left the channel
LOLOL
yeah you could look at the requests/responses in node too
Also if it helps, charles proxy works you just have to restart it every 30 minutes. i can write you an applescript to do that :stuck_out_tongue:

yeah, failing a complete monitor like Charles I'll dig into node-harvest's code. I have a strong feeling node-harvest's headers are fine (because user/pass auth works), but I want to cover my bases at least for talking to support
sorry, should have posted this in dev, huh?
are they using Bearer for their token header?
cause it looks a lot like node-harvest only supports u/p
even tho they claim oauth
typical
node-harvest looks like it supports v1 (id/secret)
I want to frame <@U02613K0X> 's comment
and point to it every time we work with a new API
<https://github.com/randomecho/harvest-api/blob/master/Authentication/OAuth%202.0.md>

attachments.title: randomecho/harvest-api
attachments.text: harvest-api - All things Harvest API. Documentation, discussion, and community creations & hacks. Come get it.

text: harvest API looks like its v2 now - so i'd look for forks of node-harvest
or fix it
<@U026PHQ3J|evans> set the channel topic: Typical
could also be something to do with refresh tokens. ugh
i'm not seeing a Bearer token header in the node-harvest code, but i could be wrong
what's Bearer?
For oauth v2, the weirdo headers got simplified into a Bearer token
so you auth once, get access token and refresh token
dump access token into header called "Bearer"
and go.
ah
<nods briefly to refresh token as "a thing you have to deal with sometimes in the simplified example above">
In light of all this stuff maybe I should just auth with john's user/pass? Using OAuth doesn't give us any extra access that u/p doesn't, just some kind of compartmentalization
as long as that u/p are stored securely
:stuck_out_tongue:
of course!
currently token/secret are encrypted via John Resig's method and only shown in plaintext on local machines (not checked-in to git) <http://ejohn.org/blog/keeping-passwords-in-source-control/>
dangit. /featurerequest markdown links
i'd also consider ditching the harvest API wrapper and just use node's request module, but that is my personal opinion
yeah, starting to think that's a solid way to go
